title: 106_hr942
content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" amends the Communications Act of 1934 by adding a new section that revises duopoly rules. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act amends duopoly rules by allowing ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations within the same market if one is a UHF station. Existing local marketing agreements between two stations in the same market are protected and exempt from the duopoly rule. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act allows ownership of two stations in separate television markets or two stations in the same market if one is a UHF station. The Commission may permit ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market under certain circumstances. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission will modify regulations to eliminate restrictions on granting broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and remove the one-to-a-market rule. Minority voting stock interests will not be considered a cognizable interest if one holder owns over 50% of the voting stock. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow ownership of broadcast stations and cable systems in the same community. Additionally, dual-network rules will be updated to permit television broadcast stations to affiliate with multiple entities. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow television broadcast stations to affiliate with multiple entities, with a deadline of 90 days for completion. SEC. 4 amends the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to increase the ownership limit to 45 percent. The Federal Communications Commission must implement this change within 90 days. SEC. 5 addresses reciprocal treatment of foreign ownership restrictions. Subsection (b) of section 310 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. No licenses shall be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with significant foreign ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. No licenses shall be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with significant foreign ownership. Foreign-controlled corporations may have their licenses refused or revoked if the public interest is deemed to be served by such actions. Additionally, reciprocal treatment for broadcast station licenses is required if the foreign country in question regularly permits broadcast station licenses. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. If a foreign government allows broadcast station licenses to be held by US persons, the Commission must allow a portion of the capital stock of the corporation seeking the license to be owned by an alien, corporation, government, or representative from that foreign country. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. The Commission must allow a portion of the capital stock of the corporation seeking the license to be owned by an alien, corporation, government, or representative from that foreign country, not exceeding 40 percent of the voting stock. The term 'United States person' includes corporations organized under US laws and US citizen individuals. The amended Communications Act of 1934 restricts foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. The definition of 'United States person' includes corporations organized under US laws, US citizen individuals, and representatives of US entities or governments.
